review_title: Avoid Oracle BDC Org At All Costs
job_title: BDC Representative in Santa Monica, CA
pros: Having the name on your resume while applying to other jobs... Although that does not seem to carry much weight anymore.
cons:
Not sure if Oracle has bots leaving fake reviews here to cover up the truth about working in the BDC org, but here is the truth: it is the most exploitative sales program out there. They randomly place BDCs into different lines of business, which end up having different pay structures. You will find yourself making more or less than someone who applied to the same role (regardless of performance). They will promise you $25k of performance-based compensation and tell you that you will get it if you hit your number during recruiting. You will end up attaining over 200% of your quota and not make full bonus. They will tell you that you can promote quickly. You will soon find out that "promotion" means getting a slightly (and I mean slightly) higher base and new title to do the same job after a year of being a BDC - if you are lucky. The road to the top at Oracle is endless.

Outside of the external competitors (who have far superior products than Oracle) you will also find yourself calling against many other teams within Oracle. This creates many confused and angry clients when you do get them on the phone or email. The training organization neglects giving you a complete understanding of the products you sell, but instead focuses on teaching you how to be manipulative and lie on the phone. The KPI structure for making bonus is nothing but subjective busy work. An "opp" does not come down to what you discover at an account, but how lenient your assigned Account Manager is.

In summary, you have no control over your destiny here. I am familiar with the common pitfalls of Corporate America. At Oracle, it is different. Leaving this company was the best decision I could have made. Hopefully this review will help someone make an even better decision of not working here at all.

review_title: Your personality has to match the culture of this organisation.
pros:
Freedom to execute on individual strategies as long as it shows positive results.
Huge focus on individual success, career promotions are based on proven individual contributions over a period of time not favouritism or nepotism.
If you have a well researched and factual business plan backed up by revenue return then it is possible to get any approval for a project in place.
Self-starters will be very successful.
cons:
Oracle impose a very aggressive and singular focus on driving revenue, to the detriment of customer relationships and CSAT. This approach is more aggressive in regions such as GULF, APAC, MEA. The company struggle to understand the value sales approach and how this relate to improving cloud consumption. The traditional on-prem license sales approach is still inherent in the management culture.
Self-Service culture can drive the most intelligent and committed individuals to become frustrated and ultimately leave.

review_title: Don't join Oracle if you want decent money to earn a living
job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Lehi, UT
pros: Good training programs, health insurance and intelligent people to work with
cons: Oracle gives a pay rise to 5% of it's employees every 2 to 3 years. So you can go 10 years and not get a pay rise. There are Engineers that exceed expectations in their performance ratings and yet do not receive a pay increase. Oracle believes you should take pride in working for Oracle rather than the money which is so sad. If you get the chance to join, negotiate a very high salary because you will not get another pay rise if you are luck enough in at least 2 to 3 years.

pros: Autonomy, management leave you to get on with your work with minimal interference. The team are very nice & helpful & will support you in your work whenever needed. The work can be interesting, a lot of very clever and motivated people who are generous with their knowledge. Great opportunities to pursue further education & learn.
cons: Labyrinthine, the place is huge so its very hard to feel part of something. No room to move around the company (despite what you may be told) - you get stuck in your role indefinitely and hit a ceiling after a few years & there is nothing your direct manager can do (they hit a wall with upper management) . Negotiate hard on entry; pay rises are few and far between - a parsimonious company.

pros: Good Benefits, Generous PTO, Flexible Work Environment
cons: Senior Management is fragmented and doesn't have a cohesive vision for the company. The vision they do have doesn't get translated well and the average employee has almost no idea how their contribution fits into the big picture. Consequently, there is constant fear regarding the VERY frequent lay off cycle. 1st, 2nd and 3rd line managers have absolutely no input on lay off, raises or bonuses - it's all decided at the Exec level (in a vacuum). The new executive leadership doesn't value expertise or track record -only the bottom line.
